ARTICLE VIII.
The Hog Island Shipyard is by
far the largest of the shipbuilding
plants which have been ordered
by the Emergency Fleet Corporation of the United States Shipping Board, and the extent of
the work can be appreciated only
after a personal visit to the site
of this enormous undertaking on
the Delaware River.
The island is about six miles
directly south from the City Hall
in Philadelphia on.the west bank
of the river. It is separated from
the mainland by a creek, which is
from two to three hundred feet
wide, and is connected to the
mainland by a steel wagon bridge
and various railroad bridges.
Before giving you figures relating to the project, let me say that
I believe there has been no justification for the attacks which have
been made on this project or
those responsible for it.
The American International
Corporation engaged the firm of
Stone & Webster, of Boston, to
undertake the work, and it has'
thus far been put through with
the customary energy and foresight for which that firm has
earned its high reputation.
Stone & Webster have done many
of the biggest engineering jobs ever
undertaken. Among them: The

Big Creek Development, $20,000,000; the Dallas (Tex.) Terminal

Company and a great many more
large undertakings, including
city gas plants, interurban railways, etc., in this country and
abroad.

Building- Dancing Follows Musical
Program-Quartet Makes Hit.

The annual concert and dance
given Friday at McCoy Hall by
the Combined Musical Clubs of
Johns Hopkins University was attended by a small but enthusiastic
audience. From the opening number, "The Star-Spangled Banner,"
till the final selection, "'Rah for
Black and Blue," the musicians
performed in pleasing and masterful style.
The quartet, composed of F. H.
Townsend, C. T. Leber, D. Coulter and C. Hardman, was especially encored; the negro dialect
songs, "Hail, Jerusalem," "Old
Black Joe," and "Pray for the
Lights to Go Out," being the favorites.
The sudden illness of Girard
Lubin, of Barn fame, prevented
the playing of a piano duet by him
and 0. W. McCleary, but Edward
Hoffmeister's piano selection was
substituted for this number. The

0. W. McCleary, piano; and P. U.

Some one was sent to "Doc" Adams' for floor wax, but making a

A Symbol of Service'.

Now We Have It; Now We Haven't It.

A symbol of service and sacrifice, an emblem of honor and glory,
is the star-strewn service flag that flies from the Barn at Homewood.
It represents the number of Hopkins men who are fighting for the
preservation of America, American ideals, and the civilization of the
world. It represents the tribute, in terms of flesh and blood, of a
humanitarian institution, which has already paid a great tribute in
research and knowledge, to mankind.
But if the service flag is merely to symbolize and immortalize the
service of Hopkins' sons, it will not serve its entire purpose. A strip
of bunting is a poor substitute for

the hearts of the men represented by blue or gold stars.
It is not for us to absorb ourselves with poetic speculations as
to the number of additional blue stars that will appear, or as to the
number of blue stars that will turn to gold. Let us leave that to
romantic old ladies. It is for us to discover how we, as college students, can best serve in this national emergency. It is for us who day
after day walk—on our way to or from classes—under the flag to translate that symbol of service into our hearts, our words, our deeds.
We have been continuing our courses at college because we have
been told that we can best serve our country in that way. It is important to observe that what are often matters of individual welfare
in times of peace become in times of war patriotic and fundamental
duties. Some examples, from the standpoint of the college student,
are: to study, to keep physically fit, to undergo military training, and,
finally, to economize. While war is essentially a test of physical

A symbol of service and sacrifice, an emblem of honor and glory,
is the star-strewn service flag that flies from the Barn at Homewood.
It represents the number of Hopkins men who are fighting for the
preservation of America, American ideals, and the civilization of the
world. It represents the tribute, in terms of flesh and blood, of a
humanitarian institution, which has already paid a great tribute in
research and knowledge, to mankind.

service of Hopkins' sons, it will not serve its entire purpose. A strip
of bunting is a poor substitute for

Universities of Virginia aud North Carolina Will Debate at Homewood.
Hopkins Debates Away.

The annual triangular debate
in which teams representing the
Johns Hopkins University, the
University of Virginia and the
University of North Carolina participate will be held on next Saturday evening in the, lecture
room of the Civil Engineering
Building. At least that was the
original intention, Mit since the
announcement of the elaborate
program by Sanner and Miegel,
chairmen of the Committees of
Arrangement and Entertainment,
such a crowd is expected that it
may be necessary to secure a larger hall
The subject for the debate is:
"Resolved, that the Government of
the United States shall immediately conscript each resident of
this.country not engaged in military duty for the duration of the
war, for such other service as the
Government shall deem each best
fitted to perform." The team representing the University of North
Carolina which is composed of
Messrs. M. B. Fowler and W. M.
York, will uphold the affirmative
side of the question, while Messrs.
George Kinsolving and Roy L.
Garris will champion the negative
side. Mr. Kinsolving is the son
of the well-known Bishop Kinsolving of this city and his presence
here is expected to act as a great
drawing card.
Moreover, a musical program
has been prepared, which includes
a galaxy of stars. First, there
will be a trio upon the 'cello, violin and piano by the Misses Broemers; then there will be a solo by
Miss Margaret Hempel, a cousin
of the world-famed Frieda Hempel; and, finally, the Johns Hopkins Quartet may be prevailed
upon to give us a few selections.
Hopkins will be represented by
Morton K. Rothschild (chairman)
and Charles H. Miegel, who will
debate on the affirmative side
against North Carolina at the
University of Virginia; Leo W.
Simon (chairman) and J. M. Berkowitz will uphold the negative
side against the University, of
Virginia at the University of
North Carolina. All of our men
are veterans whose oratorical
powers are well known, so that
we have no doubt that this year,
as usual, Hopkins will carry off
the honors.

The Hopkins nine will play
their first game away from home
this season on Saturday, when
they journey to Annapolis to meet
the clever ball tossers of Uncle
Sam's Naval Academy. With the
team continuing to improve at
the rate of the past two weeks
they should easily send the Navy
aggregation down to defeat and
get revenge for the defeat administered to our lacrosse team.
The team appears to have at
last struck a winning stride. The
men have shown up remarkably
well lately, both at practice and
in the games, and have considerably improved their weakness at
the bat that was so manifest in
the Western Maryland game.
Every man on the team has been
hitting the ball hard and the Navy
twirlers are scheduled for some
rough treatment. The lineup of
the Hopkins aggregation will not
be changed with the exception of
the shifting of "Doc" Cox to the
outfield, where he played for two
years at City College, and the stationing of J. Jones at the hot corner, due to the fact that Rogers,
who was scheduled to take care
of the third sack, has been called
into military 'service. Cox is expected to benefit very much by
the change, as "Doc" is not used
to playing the infield, while he is
perfectly at home in the outer garden. Jones, on the contrary, is a
natural infielaer and is expected
to show up very well at the third
station.
Welliver will probably be selected to start the game again against
the Annapolitans, but no definite
decision has yet been reached by
Coach Hooper, and at the last
minute either Love or Judefind
may be selected to serve up the
shoots. Capt. "Dick" Benson will
be in his usual position behind
the bat.
From all advance dope that can
be gotten on the nine of the Naval
Academy, the two teams will be
pretty evenly matched. Navy
played - Maryland State College
last week and succeeded in vanquishing them after thirteen innings of play by the score of 6 to
5—the same score that the Hopkins nine beat them by in twelve
innings. The Navy nine played
very loosely, making six errors
during the progress of the game.

The Carlisle lacrosse team will
be the attraction at Homewood
this Saturday, which means the
staging of one of the scrappiest
games of the season. The Indians
thip year are reported to be unusually strong; with practically
their entire second-string team in
the line-up they defeated Poly,
17 to 0, in the first game of the
season, and put up a splendid
game against Navy last Saturday,
losing by the close score of 3 to 1.
W. D. O'Neill, of Cornwall,
Canada, is again coaching the
Indians, and his confidence in
his team is shown by the fact
that he has arranged one of the
hardest schedules undertaken by
a collegiate lacrosse team for
years. Games are to be played
on two successive days in several
cases, Syracuse one day, and
Hobart the next, and two games
in a row with the Crescents the
latter part of May.
Practically half of the Indians
this year are veterans of last
spring. Among the old men who
will come down again are Capt.
D. Non, who has played point
for them for three years, and Ed
Miller, goalkeeper, also a veteran
of three seasons. There are also
several good new men on both attack and defense, most of them
familiar to Homewood rooters as
members of last fall's football
team. The 'Varsity will be out
for blood this Saturday to get
back at the Indians for the 6-3
beating they gave them last
spring, in the only game of the
season, when the 'Varsity was
weakened by the enlistment of
several of the regular men. The
squad seems to be in good shape
for the game at the present time,
and is bound to make things uncomfortable for the Redmen.

On Tuesday evening, April 16,
in Room 9,Gilman Hall, the Mathematics Club held one of its biweekly gatherings, with a representative and fairly large attendance. The first question decided

The first speaker on the schedule was Mr. Zahn • his subject was
"Logarithms." He began with a
brief history of logarithms. Logarithms were invented by Napier in
1614; these, however, were very
different from those we today
call "Naperian Logarithms." They
made important use of "ten to the
seventh power," and their base
was approximately the reciprocal
of e. The tables as we now have
them were invented by Briggs and
developed by Vlacq. The speaker
then demonstrated the method of
deriving logarithms with the calculus by use of Taylor's theorem.
The resulting series was used for
the first few numbers; afterwards
substitutions were made in the
variable to make the converging of
the series more rapid. With one
of these substitutions only one
term of the series was necessary,
and with a second none was needed, making the calculation only
an adding of certain quantities already obtained. The logarithms
thus obtained were changed to the
base ten by a simple theorem of
algebra. Mr. Zahn then showed
an approximate method of continuous fractions. Dr. Hulburt then
closed the discussion with a little
more of the history, stating that
the aim of the early mathematicians was to obtain a high degree
of accuracy by taking a number
of additional decimal places. This
resulted in making the tables so
large that they filled large sets of
heavy volumes.
